title: How should I motivate myself to write research papers? - Quora

response.answer_text: Research papers can be a pain. I wrote a couple of research papers for school and it can be a long and dull process. Here are some things that helped me personally: Staying consistent on a schedule.Try to schedule a specific set time, date and place when you will definitely make some progress on the paper no matter what. Choose a time that is when you are least likely to be interrupted. I personally did most of my work either late at night or early morning. Mid-day is when distractions starts to happen. If you have a deadline, let that be a motivator for you as well !Create an outline. Have a rough idea of how the research paper will appear. For example, I start with drafting up an outline and brainstorming ideas of what will go into: introduction, body and conclusionTake it one step at a time. Start with one section first. Remember that a research paper is not something that will be finished immediately. It can take a few days or sometimes weeks depending on your schedule and deadline. Keep in mind that as long as you are making progress, you are getting somewhere. Start with the easiest component to research. I usually start writing up the body first and save introduction and conclusion for last since it will be easier to summarize.Take regular 15–30 minute breaks every 1–2 hours. Get your body moving! No, don’t reach for the phone but take a walk, get up for water or healthy snacks, stretch or any other physical movement! This will refresh the brain and body especially after sitting for such a long periodKeep distractions away especially your phone! This one applies to almost everything in life when we try to focus or stay motivated on a task. Do whatever it takes to keep the phone or other things from distracting you. Find a quiet place and place your phone on silent from notifications and at a distance from you. Refuse to look at it until you have reached a certain amount of progress in your paperBonus: find help from others. This is optional and probably the last resort but you can ask a friend or classmate for help on finding additional resources for your paper. Teamwork helps a lot sometimes.Hope some of these tips helped! Best of luck! You can do it!!!

There are different ways to motivate yourself to write up your research work, and the most effective way would depend on your personality. I’ll also assume that the person asking the question is a PhD student, or an undergraduate who wants to apply to PhD programs in the future. The desire to graduate: You won’t graduate with a PhD until you publish your work in peer-reviewed journals.The desire to see the realization and culmination of all your effort: Research is hard, and you’ve probably spent months or years collecting and analyzing data, checking your hypotheses, etc. All of that work is useless until it is published and shared with the world. People don’t usually like wasting effort, so this can be good motivation.For me, the paper allows me to close research projects. I can happily say that I am done with that problem once it is published, and then move on to the next thing.To see your name in print in an academic journal: It’s a great feeling to see your name in print—to see the culmination of all the work you’ve put in.Improves your future employment options in research-oriented jobs and graduate school applications: Journal papers are a great way to show employers that you are able to do original research, and this can open the door for interesting jobs. If you’re an undergraduate student, then the paper will definitely help you with graduate school applications.The feeling of helping humanity progress due to your intellectual contributions: A good journal paper is a novel intellectual contribution to our species’ knowledge-base, and the feeling of contributing can be a motivator.A combination of all of these factors should provide the required motivation, and if it doesn’t, then you probably aren’t cut out to be a researcher.

This question itself sounds ominous ( giving the worrying impression that something unfavourable is going to happen). I am talking about scientific research here. Several Nobel laureates’ advice to those who are about to enter the research field : Go into science if you are curious and have passion for it. If not, find something else! If you are curious and passionate about science, you don’t need separate modes of motivation in the first place. Your mind will have those special characters that will have you in their tight grip. If you are not curious and passionate, even though you get motivation from outside or from your own tutored self, research will be substandard and you lose interest very soon.

If you’re not getting fired up to actually write, is there some writing-related work you can do? This might include research, finding markets to write for, writing query letters, organizing submission information, sending out submissions, reading writing books, critiquing, discussing writing in online forums, etc. Keep in mind, though, that it’s possible to spend all your time doing writing busy-work and never writing, and also keep in mind that if you really want to write at the moment, there’s almost always a way to motivate yourself to do that. With that said, if you’re going to avoid actually writing, doing so by furthering your writing career is a lot better than playing video games or raiding the cupboard.

Presumably, you are writing the research paper (that you hope to publish) because you want to tell the world about your research, and you hope to advance science or scholarship. The contents are very important to you, but they are only at the edge of other people’s consciousness. When they do discover your paper, they are usually in a hurry—soooo many other things to do—that they want to understand what you have to say quickly and effectively. If you write poorly and don’t feature what is important about your results, they will ignore what you have to say. Why do all that work in your research project, if you don’t write the paper carefully enough to have an influence on readers?

Start with developing a research topic which is interesting ( to you). Set objectives and sub objectives on how to achieve them For instance if you paper is 40 pages ( 5 chapters), in the first wk you write chapter one , in the next two weeks write literature review and so on.

Quality or our internal values are enough motivation by itself, the satisfaction of doing a good job, or even the very best craft you can muster. Motivation is a personal, internal quality, although there can be external gains. Some of us have it and others don’t.
If something has to motivate you for writing research paper, then my friend research is not for you..

Select topics for the paper based on material you are very interested in. In order to do the literature surveys required, you should have a personal knowledge of the basic material, and an intense curiosity about learning more. Only from such an initial stance will you be able to collate your findings into an informative paper.
